review_title: above-average salary, conservative, bureaucratic employer with still too little sensitivity for sexism
job_title: Finance & Controlling in Ludwigshafen am Rhein
pros: high work-life balance great benefits (gym, pension fund, employee shares, company doctor) above-average salaries international employer with sites in all regions of the world
cons: BASF has put in place several functions to adress equality and cooperative behavior but they still face a massive problem with sexism in the workplace. Overall, the company's committment at the time of writing this review is based rather on words and not on sufficient action to tackle these inequalities. In many departments, there is little sensitivity towards these issues and a lack of training of employees to become more aware of their working environment. Controversy and discussion are not an integrated element of corporate culture, neither is there a culture for failure. Hierarchies are steep which makes communication exhausting. It is difficult to pursue a career as an outsider, senior management usually has spent decades within the company. There is insufficient promotion of an empathic leadership culture with managers too often being promoted based on tenure rather than on leadership skills. Flexibility and control exercised through senior management vary from department to department with parts of the company being hybrid and flexible and others still following an absolute top down-approach.

review_title: Challenging & Rewarding Work but Toxic Culture and Poor Leadership
job_title: Marketing Manager in Florham Park, NJ
pros: Lots of projects to work on, providing many opportunities for growth (if you can navigate the system). Few established processes in some business, so much room to make something new, in addition t the many process improvements always happening. Decent benefits, but salary and bonuses not keeping up with other offers. Good opportunity for travel due to global nature of the business.
cons: Work expectations can be extreme, and unmanageable at time. Projects are ambiguous without clear process or decision makers, so everything moves so slow. Toxic culture permeates; poor treatment of women persists. Questionable hiring practices. Senior leaders often don't understand the business they have to run, and don't trust the teams doing the work for many years. More time spent writing strategy iterations than spent on executing strategy and doing the work. When projects fail, scapegoats are identified early and aggressively blamed.

review_title: Worst working experience I could possibly have
pros: Office is in the center of city International environement
cons: Administrative part is too slow and makes too many mistakes. They forgot to book me the flat we agreed on for my relocation, they made tax errors on my payslip, comunicated the wrong address to a state institution and they forgot to pay me my last salary, which they corrected but only three weeks later. Had to borrow money in order to pay my rent. Despite the fact that I told them, they didn't care too much about the urgency of the matter neither. The managers do not have managment skills and always act to defend their own interests instead of the ones of the team. Never happened to me before. They also adopt the micromanaging model of work. You have to report to them your movements and actions everyday. There are too many meetings that last too long. Which in consequence doesn't leave too much time to work, That is why there are many people in the team, Otherwise the work could be perfectly done with less people. Within the team, there is not really a structure or a good organisation. It is rather chaotic. The job position is also not the one described where you have to analyse and bring on the table your ideas. It is rather robotic, monotonous and you find yourself very fast thrown into doing something that is not what you have been trained to do nor what you have been described during the hiring process.

review_title: Ag Solutions- Penny Wise and Dollar Dumb
job_title: Research Scientist in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
-Good benefits, high salaries for the field
-Good teammates, many at the top of their field. Highly depends on your team
-Opportunities for growth within company
-Company handled COVID and now the hybrid environment coming out of COVID well.
cons:
Corporate is always demanding innovation, but never wants to spend the money to drive it. No matter how well the business does, research budgets remain flat year to year or get cut slightly. They also don’t like to add head count, so they demand more and more from less and less people.

Company processes are inefficient and wasteful. They have literally millions of dollars collecting dust in the basement, equipment that remains broken because nobody has the budget to fix it. I literally saw them throw out hundreds of thousands of dollars of brand new lab supplies during a re-organization. That stuff could’ve paid my salary for a decade.

Everything has to be decided by committee so everything moves at a slow pace. Company is a beast of burden.

Internal systems are terrible. Never seen a company with such terrible IT where redundant systems don’t talk to each other and you need to do the same thing over and over because little data is stored.

Teams are surprisingly insular for a company with such global reach. Everyone tends to retreat to their silos, so collaboration is more difficult than it should be. This is largely team dependent, some can be agile in this regard.

job_title: Facilities Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Good benefits
Work - life balance
Location in RTP
cons: Company loses its ability to innovate with so many restrictions from “supporting” groups such as procurement/IT/Saftey. Getting anything done becomes a headache and a burden. Getting a PO for a vendor who is the best for the end result is an enormous task when you have to get them through a system called Avetta, then you have to fight procurement on thier recommendations who have no clue the end result of the preferred vendors output. They only understand the input to the vendor - aka how much money. Don’t forget you get what you pay for. Imagine the money that could be saved yearly by not having these “support” groups. Any money saved by getting a cheap vendor is offset anyways by the departments yearly overhead, but the added work and frustration caused by having the non technical group try to steer the technical folks on whom they deem as the best supplier could be a great step in allowing for more freedom to do one’s job.

pros: BASF keeps a very respectful and friendly with atmosphere.
cons: BASF has a dirty secret. 91% of its executives in the US are caucasian, 3% Asian, and 3% AA. BASF has been strongly pushing diversity in manufacturing and increasing diversity in the manufacturing VPs. However, diversity in BASF manufacturing means caucasian women only.  That measily 3% Asian and 3% AA representation is on the business side. The manufacturing side has almost no POC in the executives. If you are Asian or AA in manufacturing and desire to be an executive, then BASF is not a fit for you. If you are male and a POC in manufacturing then you will not become an executive at BASF. I hope one day BASF proves me wrong, but so far they have made it very clear through their actions that diversity in BASF manufacturing = caucasian women only.

cons: Opportunities can be limited at smaller sites, and many of them have high turnover and a less open-minded culture. The company reorganizes things a lot and tends to outsource things like IT to other countries, making it harder to get specific access rights. While employees are not often laid off, many roles are lost due to attrition and not backfilled.

pros: BASF provides excellent benefits, has leading technology, and some really intelligent people that contribute to ongoing business success. Compensation is very good. Business Unit and the Segment / Division performance influence compensation. I was grateful for the opportunity to work across multiple markets and industries.
cons:
Sales and Marketing at BASF are very challenging positions with many factors out of your control. Manufacturing performance and raw material drivers have enormous impacts on your ability to achieve objectives. Although these factors are dynamic, your goals are not, so prepare for that if pursuing these roles. They recognize the importance of collaboration. Some groups just aren't necessarily willing collaborators all the time. 
 Manufacturing, Supply Chain, and Purchasing seem to have more power within BASF.   Sales is expected to support these other groups without question.  As a Sales professional, a great deal of time was spent managing problems that directly impacted customers due to actions or decisions made by these groups.  It seemed we were very internally focused.

job_title: Crop Production Manager II in Champaign, IL
pros: The group I work with in Agriculture solutions is absolutely wonderful. I am able to complete my work with upper managements complete support and confidence in my abilities. There is flexibility in ways of working, especially with a young family during the challenging pandemic environment. When assistance is needed, colleagues and management is willing to drop what they are doing and assist with the tasks.
cons: Within my organization, opportunities for advancement do not occur very often as people often sit in positions for quite some time. There are some that also seem to believe in quantity of employees vs quality of employees, which can be frustrating at times.

pros:
1. High Compensation compared to Indian counterparts for same role.

2. Exposure to multiple job functions in 1st year of training.

3. Access to lot of learning materials (LinkedIn Learning, SuccessFactors, Udemy, Instructor led training)

4. Companies tag will help you in your future roles and growth.

5. Lots of opportunities within BASF after 2 years completion (different roles, functions, business units)

6. Employee Benefits include Term insurance, medical insurance, transportation, reward and recognition.

7. Lots of top connections can be made within/outside company and you can take advantage of this connections in future.

8. Safe working conditions compared to Indian counterparts and this is the decision maker for people who want to opt for production roles in this company.
cons:
1. Pathetic work culture on the site, cannot compare it with the work culture at head office/corporate offices. No mutual respect for team members. Only money matters for people working here.

2. People working at the site are locales/regional. So, they talk in their regional language and they don't care whether an outsider understands what they speak which is the worst nature of professionalism.

3. Colleagues at the site will interfere a lot with your personal life and it is not at all suitable for someone who has an introverted personality.

4. Work location is very isolated (Mangalore/Dahej), so local people are highly conservative and they don't allow you to practice city culture. No girl/boy allowed to visit boys/girls house, else society will take action against you and ask you to empty their room.

5. Local people are highly hesitant to give a room for rent to Bachelor's/married people not living with their wife. So, finding a room is hell of a task for a bachelor. Broker's take advantage of this and they charge higher to Bachelor's. Company also doesn't provide accomodation, so very difficult to find a home for someone from outside the city.

6. Living away from family in a place like Mangalore/Dahej can be very lonely and if you don't have colleague's/friends of your own age, it will be very difficult to survive considering that there is no place to hangout (malls, cafe, beaches, tourist attractions, etc)

7. No public transport, no Ola/Uber, no rental services, desolated railway station means that transport system is not at all good and it will make your travelling hell.

8. Site is located far away from City, so if you decide to live in a city, there will be 3-4 hour travelling everyday. Overall 13-14 hours of the day will go in job and no life after job. No employee accomodation provided by the company.

9. Working in Shifts means you will have no sleep cycle and health issues due to lack/excess of sleep.

10. Whatever things you learn in Chemical Engineering in UG, it will be of no use to you. There is no need of Chemical Engineering Knowledge at these sites. People with Diploma can handle the plant functioning best.

11. No professional growth, though your technical knowledge will grow. If you want to move to other job functions, this role is not meant for you. People who are in this role are mainly there beacuse of either their love for Production or lack of opportunities in other roles.

12. Production role is highly monotonous, it involves exposure to same things in work everyday. 8-hour shifts is what you need to do. Nothing new happens and this can be very boring for someone who loves challenges/new experiences from work life.

Micro management is common on all teams. Although it is claimed that there is a horizontal structure in all discourses, internal/external documents or meetings, there is a completely vertical administration. Persons do not matter in the slightest in this company. They try to create artificial competition within the team for low wages, but everyone knows the decisions that are NOT transparent.

review_title: Leader in Diversity and Inclusion but Lagging in Efficiency and Competitiveness
pros: The company is very focused on hiring diverse candidates and promoting inclusion among the workforce. The senior managers focus on work/life balance and addressing social issues. This is great and makes for a good work environment. The salaries are very competitive and the overall compensation package is very attractive.
cons: There are a lot of inefficiencies, waste and complexity in the organization. The various business units operate in silos and the leaders are not always concerned with the health of the company overall, but are more concerned with their own division. It is very difficult for a new employee to learn to navigate the many layers of the business. Your support teams are very often located in different parts of the world and it makes it difficult to know who is responsible for what aspect of the business.

review_title: don't work here if you'Re ambitious
pros: it is an OK job if you just want to have easy tasks and don't mind the minimum salary and the mind-numbing work.
cons:
* be prepared to be underpaid and frustrated: this is a fundamental part of this job that you need to accept; the company BASF Service Europa was supposed to be established in an Eastern European country to keep the wages expenses low, BASF only agreed to create the company in Berlin after it created a separate salary agreement for BASF Service Europa that allows the company to keep the salaries low. 

* digitalization and automation are two keywords that you will hear all the time in meetings and in always-recurring company initiatives, yet from what I have seen most of the company employees are stuck doing repetitive monotonic jobs and very few people have the competence and right mindset to help with digitalization since they are being picked mainly based on their willingness to accept low salaries. 

This leads to a company culture were on the surface everything is nice and friendly but most employees are doing the bare minimum with low efficiency and productivity.

review_title: Lots of Pros, Lots of Cons
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Florham Park, NJ
pros:
Great benefits - 4 weeks paid vacation
10% to 401K - paid by company
Comprehensive health insurance options
Paid maternity and paternity leave
Sophisticated Work
cons:
Strata system - A promotion is not a true promotion. Most of the time it is just a better title with no additional compensation.
Long Term Incentives - Only available to a few people. Positions that are Director-level at similar companies are only Manager-level at BASF and ineligible for long term incentives. Can result in substantial pay differences between BASF and non-BASF positions.
Limited promotion opportunities.
Poor bonuses 
Middle of the pack financial performance when compared to other large chemical companies.
Raises are generally lower than those at other companies. Typically 2 to 2.5% a year as compared to 3% to 4% a year at other large companies.
"Diversity" is just another way of saying we hire and promote white women. Limited focus on racial ethnic diversity in managerial positions.
